Retrieved July 27, 2009, [https://www.solgps.alberta.ca/programs_and_services/correctional_services/young_offenders/youth_justice_committees/Pages/default.aspx Alberta.ca]</ref> YJCs aim to "strike the right balance between accountability and community intervention"<ref name=YJC2>Youth Justice Committees of Ontario. "Fact Sheets." Retrieved July 27, 2009, [http://www.yjcontario.ca/factsheets.php YJContario.ca]</ref> YJCs are used extensively in Manitoba, Alberta and New Brunswick. A committee's activity largely depends on volunteer efforts from its community.<ref name=YJC1/> Trained members work to create extrajudicial measures for young people, but failure to comply with measures given ultimately results in return to the formal justice system.<ref name=YJC1/>
==Right to counsel==
===General=== The ''Act'' in Section 25(1) gives a youth the right to retain and instruct counsel without delay,<ref name="YCJA">{{cite web|url=http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html|title=Page not Found - Page non trouvé|website=justice.gc.ca|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181651/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html|archivedate=July 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> which was amended by the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]]. This means that young persons who are arrested or detained for any reason must be told of their right to obtain a lawyer before any lawful procedures are conducted.<ref name="YCJA2">{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/10right-droit/3100301a.html|title=We couldn't find that Web page (Error 404) - Department of Justice / Nous ne pouvons trouver cette page Web (Erreur 404) - Ministère de la Justice|website=www.justice.gc.ca|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032716/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/10right-droit/3100301a.html|archivedate=June 14, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The youth must also be given the '''opportunity''' to obtain this counsel. If the youth does not have a lawyer present at the first court date, the judge '''must''' inform the youth of their right of counsel. Before accepting a plea, the court must
# Ensure that the young person understands the charge # Explain the plea options # Explain the process of applying a youth sentence
The young person has right to counsel upon arrest or detention, before a voluntary statement, during consideration of extrajudicial sanctions, and at a hearing.<ref name="YCJA2"/> If the youth is denied legal aid for any reason, the court can order that counsel be given to the youth- in order to comply with the right to counsel<ref name="Reference">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T1osO9jQJa8C&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=right+to+counsel+youth+25(1)&source=bl&ots=qdyZCpfEMt&sig=JtsA173Vd1f7iDJBCRuattpx1kA&hl=en&ei=Dy5tSq7HB464MP3o2fgG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5|title=Responding to Youth Crime in Canada|first1=Anthony N.|last1=Doob|first2=Carla|last2=Cesaroni|date=November 8, 2017|publisher=University of Toronto Press|via=Google Books}}</ref> If at any point the parent's interests and the youth's interests are in conflict, the presiding judge may also order counsel be obtained for the youth<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T1osO9jQJa8C&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=right+to+counsel+youth+25(1)&source=bl&ots=qdyZCpfEMt&sig=JtsA173Vd1f7iDJBCRuattpx1kA&hl=en&ei=Dy5tSq7HB464MP3o2fgG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5%5D,|title=Responding to Youth Crime in Canada|first1=Anthony N.|last1=Doob|first2=Carla|last2=Cesaroni|date=November 8, 2017|publisher=University of Toronto Press|via=Google Books}}</ref> Even though right to counsel is guaranteed by the ''Act'', studies have shown that youth tend to not take advantage of counsel, leading many to question the validity and authenticity of Section 25(1).<ref name= "Ref">Peterson-Badali, M., Abramovitch, R., Koegl, C.J., & Ruck, M.D. (1999). Young People's Experience of the Canadian Youth Justice System: Interacting with Police and Legal Counsel. Behavioural Sciences and the Law, 17: 455–465, Obtained July 27, 2009.</ref>
===Appointment of counsel=== The delivery of legal [[counsel]] has two primary models: Judicare and Staff delivery model text to display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/rs/rep-rap/1997/tr97_8-rt97_8/toc-tdm.html|title=We couldn't find that Web page (Error 404) - Department of Justice / Nous ne pouvons trouver cette page Web (Erreur 404) - Ministère de la Justice|website=www.justice.gc.ca|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033145/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/rs/rep-rap/1997/tr97_8-rt97_8/toc-tdm.html|archivedate=June 14, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In judicare delivery model, lawyers in private practice are issued certificates to provide legal aid to clients. In the staff lawyer system, the service is provided by lawyers that are employed directly by the legal aid plan. The proportion of Young offender legal aid is equally divided between the two.<ref>Canada. Department of Justice. Legal Aid Delivery Models in Canada. Web. July 26, 2009. [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/rs/rep-rap/1999/tr99_1-rt99_1/p1.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032947/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/rs/rep-rap/1999/tr99_1-rt99_1/p1.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> Section 25 of the ''Act'' outlines the young individual's right to counsel, which was amended from the Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms. The aim is to protect the youth's right to counsel in all stages of the youth justice process and ensure the individual understands the justice process.<ref>Youth Criminal Justice Act." John Howard Society of Canada. John Howard Society of Canada. Web. July 26, 2009. [http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf AB.ca] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802120035/http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf |date=August 2, 2010 }}</ref> According to the ''Act'' section 25 (4): If the young individual is unable to obtain legal assistance or no legal aid program is available, the young offender is able to request counsel. The counsel to represent the young individual is to be appointed by the [[Attorney General]] according to the section 25(5) of the Youth Justice Act.<ref>Canada. Department of Justice. YCJA Explained. December 13, 2008. July 26, 2009. [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181651/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> For example, if the young individual is unable to afford a lawyer, he or she may request legal aid. If eligible, a lawyer will be appointed by the attorney general.
===Assistance by adult=== The Canadian Charter of rights and freedoms and the ''Act'' both hold the right to legal representation for youth. The purpose is to provide extensive opportunity for legal advocacy and advice prior to and during the court process.<ref>Minaker, Joanne and Hogeveen, Bryan. 2009. "The Operation of the youth criminal Justice System". pg 101–102 in Youth, Crime and Society:Issues of power and Justice. Toronto: Pearson</ref> However, when a young person is not represented by counsel at trial or at a hearing, the justice presiding over the case or the youth justice court may allow youth to be assisted by an adult at the request of the young person<ref name="Justice 2008">Department of Justice. 2008. "Youth Criminal Justice Act: Right to Counsel Section 25(7)". Retrieved July 23, 2009, Department of Justice Canada [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181651/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102500.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> For this to occur, the youth court of justice or the review board must find an adult who is deemed to be suitable in assisting the young person.<ref name="Justice 2008"/> This right is given to make the process for the young person easier, as the young person can obtain adult assistance from someone that they are more familiar with.<ref name="Michele Peterson Pg 455-465">Michele Peterson, R.A. "Young Person's Experience of the Canadian Youth Justice System: Interacting with Police and Legal Counsel". Pg 455–465. John Wiley and Sons Ltd 1999</ref> Despite the fact that section 25(7) does not specify specific requirements for the ideal suitable adult, this tends to be assessed on a case by case basis to the specific needs of the young person.<ref name="Michele Peterson Pg 455-465"/>
===Statement to youth=== The Statement of Right to Counsel requires that the young person be provided with a written statement that reminds them that they do have the right to request and be represented by legal counsel at any time during the judicial process.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act 2002">Youth Criminal Justice Act, S.C. 2002, c. 1.</ref> Included at various stages of the judicial process, the Statement, ensures that the young person remains alert to their rights, to the continued availability of counsel and to their options for counsel (i.e., Legal Aid).<ref>Bala, N. 2003. Youth Criminal Justice Law. Toronto: Irwin Law, p318</ref> The Statement must be included with appearance notices or summons, arrest warrants, promises to appear, in all notifications of sentence review and also with all undertakings or recognisance that the young person may participate in under the auspices of the officer in charge.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act 2002"/> It must also be included with other notifications of legal proceedings such as custody continuations, conditional supervision, decision reviews and all youth justice court reviews.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act 2002"/> The repetition of the document serves as a reminder not only to the young person, but also to those within the judicial system that it is necessary to protect the rights of the young person and guarantee that those rights are upheld throughout the judicial process.<ref>Peterson-Badali, M., Care, S., & Broeking, J. 2007. "Young People's Perceptions and Experiences of the Lawyer-Client Relationship". Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice, 49(3), 375–401.</ref>
===Explanation appropriate to age and understanding=== Every accused person in Canada has the right to be informed of their rights and what they are being charged of, according to the legal rights of the Arrest and Detention section of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/charter/1.html#anchorbo-ga:l_I-gb:s_7|title=Page not Found - Page non trouvé|website=laws.justice.gc.ca}}</ref><ref>Charter of Rights and Freedoms.1981."Department of Justice-legal rights", Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/charter/1.html#anchorbo-ga:l_I-gb:s_7 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> According to section 146 (2) (b) of the ''Act'', Young persons under the age of 18 must have their rights explained by the officer in a language appropriate to their age and level of understanding. Therefore, the officer must assess the accused youth's ability to understand their rights before attaining a statement from the youth. It is imperative that the officer states the rights to the youth in a manner that he or she fully understands due to the fact that the courts will not assess whether the child fully understood the rights inform to them by the officer but whether or not the officer explained their rights at a level appropriate to their age and understanding.<ref name="canada.justice.gc.ca">Department of Justice Canada.2008. "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: Summary and Background." Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://canada.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/ycja-lsjpa/back-hist.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620125810/http://canada.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/ycja-lsjpa/back-hist.html |date=June 20, 2009 }}</ref>
Officers employ such techniques as having the youth repeat or summarize in their own words the rights that were transmitted to them to avoid having any testimonies made by the accused youth waived by the courts.<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "The Youth Criminal Justice Act Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/01extjud/3010301b.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032957/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/01extjud/3010301b.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref>
===Right to counsel 25(3)=== The fundamental paradigm shift from the ''Youth Offenders Act'' to the ''Youth Criminal Justice Act'' involves the view that deviant youth are now viewed as offenders responsible for their actions. In a similar comparison to that of adults, the youth are encouraged to obtain legal counsel.<ref>Hogaveen, B. & Smandych, R. (2001). Origins of the Newly Proposed Canadian Youth Criminal Justice Act: Political Discourse and the Perceived Crisis in Youth Crime in the 1990s. Toronto: Harcourt.</ref> The youth justice court or review board is required as a legal implication to advise the young person of their right to counsel. The following are some typical situations that warrant such advice: at a hearing for the youth when determining to detain or release the individual, at a youth's trial, and in situations where the custody of the youth is in question such as conditional supervision and decision reviews. The youth justice court or review board is more specifically required to provide a reasonable opportunity to obtain such counsel and this act is viewed as a mandated judicial measure.<ref>Pearson, J. (1992). Legal Representation under the Young Offenders Act. Toronto: University of Toronto Press.</ref> A specific difference in comparison to adult courts is the fact that it prohibits criminal proceedings against a youth without the consent of the Attorney General. In terms of adult proceedings, it is possible for members of the public to commence proceedings without the authorization of police and the Crown Attorney; however, that is not the case with youth. While comparing the ''Youth Offenders Act'' to the ''Youth Criminal Justice Act'', the former focuses more on a youth's choice to retain counsel and the role of lawyers in the criminal justice system. In terms of the JDA, more focus was placed on a youth being viewed as a misguided individual who required guidance from the courts.<ref>Tustin, L. & Lutes, R. (2005). A Guide to the Youth Criminal Justice Act. Markham: LexisNexis Canada.</ref>
==Notice to parents== Under the ''Act'', in case of the arrest or detention of a young person, the officer in charge must give notice to a parent either orally or in writing as soon as they possibly can under section 26(1).<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Notice to Parents " Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_2::bo-ga:l_3/20090723/en?page=3&isPrinting=false#codese:2 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> The notice must include under section 26(6) the following information: (a) the name of the young person (b) the charge against the young person and (c) a statement that the young person has the right to be represented by counsel.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Notice to Parents " Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_2::bo-ga:l_3/20090723/en?page=3&isPrinting=false#codese:2/ Justice.gc.ca]</ref> In addition, if summons, appearance of notice or promise to appear is issued in respect of a young person, the parent must be given notice in writing in person or via mail under section 26(2).<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Notice to Parents " Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_2::bo-ga:l_3/20090723/en?page=3&isPrinting=false#codese:2 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> Both sections 26(1) and 26(2) are subject to subsection 26(4), which states that if the whereabouts of the parents of the young person are not available, notice may be given to an adult who the person giving the notice considers appropriate.<ref name="site.ebrary.com">{{cite web|last=Bala|first= Nicholas|year= 2002|title=Youth Criminal Justice Law - Essential of Canadian Law|accessdate= July 27, 2009|url=http://site.ebrary.com/lib/utoronto/docDetail.action?docID=10200604 |website=www.utoronto.ca}}</ref> If there is a failure to give notice to a parent upon the arrest of a young person all proceedings continue and are not considered invalid under this act.<ref>John Howard Society. 2007. "Youth Criminal Justice Act Handbook" Criminal Justice Education. Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf JohnHoward.ab.ca] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802120035/http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf |date=August 2, 2010 }}</ref>
==Arrest and detention== Youths may be arrested by the police for more serious offences. The rights expressed in the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] apply to youths and adults.
Youths and adults have the right to obtain immediate legal counsel of their own choice upon arrest or detention. The Youth offender also has the right to have their parent(s) or guardian(s) present during questioning. Upon arrest or detainment, these rights must be explained in clear and understandable language.
If the police have violated the above rights, the charges may be dismissed by a judge or any statements made to the police may be ruled inadmissible by the judge in court.
Presumptive offences were found to be unconstitutional and are no longer included in the ''Act''. A presumptive offence is an offence committed or alleged to have been committed by a young person who has attained the age of fourteen years.<ref name="justice.gc.ca|date">{{cite web|title=Department of Justice|url= http://www.justice.gc.ca|date= December 2008|accessdate= July 16, 2009}}</ref> An adult sentence can be imposed on a young person who is found guilty of an offence for which an adult can be sentenced to imprisonment for more than two years if the offence was committed after a young person is fourteen years of age.<ref name="Bala, Nicholas 2002. Pages 25 & 27">Bala, Nicholas. Youth Criminal Justice Law. November 2002. Pages 25 & 27. Irwin Law</ref> Presumptive offence may be used under one of the following charges: first-degree or second-degree murder, attempt to commit murder, manslaughter or aggravated sexual assault.<ref name="justice1208">[http://www.justice.gc.ca Department of Justice], December 2008. Retrieved July 16, 2009</ref> Other serious offences can fall within presumptive offence if it is the third conviction for such an offence.<ref name="Jobb, Dean 2006. Page 186">Jobb, Dean. Media Law for Canadian Journalists. 2006. Page 186. Emond Montgomery Publications. Toronto</ref> The media is allowed to identify the youth who receives a sentence for a presumptive offence.<ref name="Jobb, Dean 2006. Page 186"/> The Judge will decide to identify the young person if a) There is reason to believe the young person is a danger to others. b) Publication of the information is necessary to assist in apprehending the young person.<ref name="Bala, Nicholas 2002. Pages 25 & 27"/> The age of fourteen may sometimes be raised in a province where the Lieutenant Governor in council has fixed the age greater than fourteen.<ref name="justice1208"/> Youths who are 12 or 13 at the time of the offense may be sentenced in the same way, only for the following: first degree or second degree murder or manslaughter.
==Right to counsel 25(4) and (10)== {{duplication|date=July 2013}} A young person at trial has the right to instruct counsel without delay, where the right to counsel is usually imposed by a young person instead of a parent. Sections 25(4) and (10) allow young people to obtain the same rights as adults, in terms of legal counsel, consent, etc. It is also necessary that young persons be given the right to consult a parent or other adult in some circumstances.<ref name="rcmp-grc.gc.ca">Royal Canadian Mounted Police. "Sections of the Youth Criminal Justice Act of Special Interest to Law Enforcement." Part 3- Judicial Measures ss. 23–37, Retrieved July 25, 2009 [http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/ycja-lsjpa/sections-articles-eng.htm#Part3 RCMP-GRC.gc.ca]</ref>
Subsection 25(10) of the ''Act'' permits provinces to establish a program for the recovery of costs of a young person's counsel from the young person or the parents of that young person.<ref name="rcmp-grc.gc.ca"/> Therefore, young people are represented by permanent salaried legal aid lawyers or, as per the specified choice, by a private lawyer who accepts the legal aid mandate payable according to the pre-established rates. If a young offender is ineligible he is represented by a private lawyer at a cost agreed upon by the youth and/or his parents and the lawyer.<ref> Trahan, Dominique. 2004. "Legal Representation of Children." National and International Perspectives. International Bureau for Children's Right. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.ibcr.org/editor/assets/conference/11trahan_eng.pdf IBCR.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607095144/http://www.ibcr.org/editor/assets/conference/11trahan_eng.pdf |date=June 7, 2011 }} </ref>
==Trial procedures== Trials for both adults and youths follow the same [[Rules of evidence|rules for evidence]] and are equally formal. {{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
==Privacy== Section 110 of the ''Act'' outlines [[privacy]] in relation to the identity of young offenders, access to their criminal records, and disclosure of their personal or trial information.<ref name = "Youth Criminal Justice Act">[http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_6/20090724/en#anchorbo-ga:l_6 Justice.gc.ca], June 2009. Retrieved July 22, 2009</ref>
The ''Act'' trial information can be published in media or print but identifying information (i.e., name) about young offenders cannot.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> This publication ban exists to prevent stigmatization of young offenders, which has been found to hinder the rehabilitation of youth.<ref name = "Youth Criminal Justice Law">Bala, Nicholas. 2002. Youth Criminal Justice Law. Toronto. Irwin Law. Pp. 381–388</ref> Furthermore, the identity of youth victims cannot be published for the same reasons.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> Breaking the publication ban is a criminal offence.<ref name="Criminal Offence">{{cite web|url=http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/07public/3070301f.html|title=Le portail de la Justice au Canada - Votre portail de l'actualité judiciaire au Canada avec des articles, actualités, informations pour vous aider.|website=Le portail de la Justice au Canada|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706183810/http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/07public/3070301f.html|archivedate=July 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It is unknown whether publication of identifying information on social networking sites like Facebook is a violation of the ban, which has been the source of recent controversy.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/News/article/290941/Rengel TheStar.com], January 2008. Retrieved July 22, 2009.</ref>
The ban can be lifted only under exceptional circumstances: *when the youth offender receives an adult sentence;<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> *when young offenders are accused or convicted of presumptive offences;<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> *if the identifying information is necessary for the capture of a young offender;<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> *or if the young offender requests for their name to be published.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act"/> Youth requests for publication are subject to judicial discretion.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Law"/>
Youth criminal records cannot be viewed by anyone other than criminal justice officials (e.g. lawyers) and only within particular time frames from the offence.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Law"/>
Disclosure ("the communication of information other than by way of publication"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5//20090723/en?page=1|title=Page not Found - Page non trouvé|website=laws.justice.gc.ca}}</ref> of youth information is banned under the ''Act''.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Law"/> Communicating information about youth offenders through disclosure is a criminal offence<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/07public/3070301f.html JusticeCanada.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706183810/http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/07public/3070301f.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}, Retrieved July 22, 2009</ref>
===Identity disclosure=== The ''Act'' allows the public and media to attend the trials of the youths and proceedings may be reported, but the identity of the youth can only be disclosed under special circumstances. The names of 15- to 17-year-olds who are convicted of serious, violent crimes, such as murder or aggravated sexual assault, can be reported in the media. If the youth is considered to be dangerous, their picture can be published in the media along with their name. Their name may also be revealed if they are still "at large" (have not been arrested yet) for the benefit of the public's safety when the expectation is that they will be charged once police have tracked them down.
On January 1, 2008, the ''Act'''s Privacy clause was tested when several users of the Internet social networking site Facebook posted the identities of murdered Toronto teenager [[Stefanie Rengel]] and her killers (Melissa Todorovic<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=July 28, 2009|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2009/07/28/rengel-sentence.html|title=Rengel's murderer sentenced to life|publisher=CBC |location=Canada CBC|date=July 28, 2009}}</ref> and David Bagshaw<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rengel killer sentenced to life|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/toronto/story/2009/09/28/rengel-killer-sentencing265.html|publisher=CBC |location=Canada |date=September 28, 2009|accessdate=September 28, 2009}}</ref>) in defiance of both the publication ban and the fact that the police had not yet received the consent of Rengel's family to release her name to the media.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20080105.STAB05%2FTPStory%2FTPNational%2FOntario%2F&ord=2107530&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true "Facebook proves problematic for police"], ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', January 5, 2008.</ref> While police and Facebook staff attempted to comply with the privacy regulations by deleting such posts, they noted that it was difficult to effectively police the individual users who repeatedly republished the deleted information.<ref>[http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/248379/Angry_Facebook_Users_Illegally_Leaked_the_Names_of_Accused_Underage_Murderers "Angry Facebook Users Illegally Leaked the Names of Accused Underage Murderers"], ''Digital Journal'', January 5, 2008.</ref>
==Detention prior to sentencing section 29== Under the ''Act'', prior to conviction, detention is prohibited and deemed unnecessary.<ref name="Department of Justice">[http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102900.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181655/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60102900.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}, Department of Justice. The Youth Criminal Justice Act section 29.</ref> One of the new provisions of the ''Act'' is to limit the use of pre-trial detention and to promote alternatives to incarceration.<ref name="YCJA Explained">[http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/03detent/3030301a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210171207/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/03detent/3030301a.html |date=December 10, 2008 }}, Department of Justice. YCJA Explained: Pre-Trial Detention Explanatory Text.</ref> Under the ''Youth Offenders Act'', pre-trial detention was on the rise and Canada, out of the western countries, had one of the highest youth incarceration rates.<ref name="YCJA References">[http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/4ref-ren/4000301a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181702/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/4ref-ren/4000301a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}, Department of Justice. YCJA Explained: References.</ref> Not only was the use of pre-trial detention high, it also varied widely across the provinces.<ref name="YCJA Explained"/> Pre-trial detention is not meant to be punitive, but research found negative outcomes associated with it as well, such as depravity{{Clarify|date=November 2009}} of freedom and seclusion from the outside world. Many youth in custody prior to their sentencing were also found guilty more often than youths not in custody.<ref name="YCJA References"/> The inconsistent use of pre-trial detention and negative connotations were cause enough for revision.
==Purpose of sentencing==
===Purpose=== The fundamental purpose in the sentencing of young persons pursuant to the ''Act'' is to strike the best possible balance between the interests of the young person and the interests of society. The sentencing judge will also endeavour to impose a sentence that encourages the youth to take responsibility for the consequences of their actions.[s.3, s.38 YCJA]
In cases of very serious crime such as murder, the ''Act'' makes provision for the imposition of an adult sentence upon the youthful offender. In such cases the onus to establish that the young person should be sentenced as an adult is on the prosecution, by virtue of the 2008 Supreme Court of Canada decision ''R v DB''.[2008 SCC 25]
Canadian appellate courts and the Supreme Court of Canada have repeatedly affirmed the principle that young persons convicted of crimes must be sentenced differently from adults. A notable example is the Ontario decision of ''R v D.T''. '2006 OJ 112' (Citation is wrong) where the Court asserted that a separate youth sentencing process is fundamental to Canadian societal notions of justice.
In ''R v C.D. / C.D.K''[2005 SCC 78], the Supreme Court of Canada confirmed that youths will receive the most favourable interpretation available of the ''Act'''s sentencing provisions . In ''C.D / C.D.K.'', the Court ruled that 'violent crime' as defined in s.39 of the ''Act'' did not include arson; the offender was thereby entitled to a more lenient disposition.[ibid, 85]
Since the enactment of the ''Act'' in 2003, a greater number of young persons charged with criminal offences have received the benefit of ''diversion'' that was the practice under the former ''Young Offenders Act''.[Bala (2007), 7]. Diversion refers to the broad range of non-criminal sanctions, including community service that if satisfactorily completed by the youth, the subject charge is withdrawn.
===Committal to custody=== Section 39 (1) of the ''Act'' maintains that a custodial sentence should not be imposed on young offenders unless certain mandatory conditions outlined in the section are satisfied.<ref name="justiceyouthsentencing3040301">Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> The purpose of this section is to provide specific guidance to judges who are considering imposing a custodial sentence with the principal focus of reducing Canada's "over-reliance on the incarceration of non-violent young persons".<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> Section 39 (1) (a) specifically places restrictions on the use of custodial sentences for non-violence offences<ref>Rock, Nora. 2005. "Children and Criminality." Child Protection and Canadian Law: A Service Perspective, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZtSX-MWjhM0C&pg=PA65&lpg=PA65&dq=youth+criminal+justice+act+s+39&source=bl&ots=X4p523Drzm&sig=8Dq312wnoxpGNHsD1fxNTotdVEw&hl=en&ei=oiptSr_IIYaINLzzyfgG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9 Books.Google.ca]</ref> unless the offender has a history of failing to comply with noncustodial sentences, has an extensive pattern of non-violent offending, or other exceptional circumstances.<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> In addition to satisfying at least one of the conditions of section 39(1), the courts must also ensure the balance of section 39 when considering a custodial sentence of a non-violent offence. Also, the judges must take into account any rehabilitative concerns that would alter the nature and reduce the severity of the sentence by mitigating factors.<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> For an example, courts must be certain to not impose a severe sentence in situations of rehabilitative of child welfare concerns. For an example, a custodial sentence should not be imposed to achieve rehabilitation purposes or to tackle such social circumstances such as lack of housing or an abusive home environment.
Section 39 of the ''Act'' restricts the use of custodial sentences for young persons<ref name="Evaluating the youth criminal justice act after five years: A qualified success">Bala, N., Carrington, P. J., & Roberts, J. V., 2009. Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice/Revue Canadienne De Criminologie Et De Justice Penale, 51(2):402. Retrieved July 26, 2009.</ref><ref name="Youth Court Statistics, 2003/04">[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/85-002-x2005004-eng.pdf Statcan.gc.ca], Thomas, Jennifer. Statistics Canada: Catalogue no. 85-002-XPE, Vol. 25(4): 7. Retrieved July 26, 2009.</ref> This means that the young person should not be taken into custody unless the young person or their offence meet certain criteria. Subsection (1) (d) defines one of these criteria and states that custodial sentences may be used in those exceptional cases where the youth has committed an indictable offense. Further, the nature of the indictable offense must be such that imposing a non-custodial sentence would not fulfil the purpose and principles of sentencing as outlined in section 38 of the ''Act''.<ref name="The Youth Criminal Justice Act: Section 39">[http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103900.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032726/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103900.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}, Department of Justice. December 13, 2008. Retrieved July 26, 2009.</ref> Section 38 of the ''Act'' states that the young person is to be held accountable for their actions and rehabilitated into society.<ref name=autogenerated3>Bala, N., Carrington, P. J., & Roberts, J. V., 2009. Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice/Revue Canadienne De Criminologie Et De Justice Penale, 51(2):144. Retrieved July 26, 2009.</ref> Thus, as defined in 39 (1) (d), custodial sentences and imprisonment and to be used only in response to offences that are indictable and when non-custodial sentences are inappropriate with regards to the circumstances and the nature of the offence.
===Alternatives to custody=== 39.(2) "If any of 39(1)(a) to (c) apply, a youth justice court shall not impose a custodial sentence under section 42 unless the court has considered all alternatives to custody raised at the sentencing hearing that are reasonable in the circumstances, and determined that there is not a reasonable alternative, or combination of alternatives, that is in accordance with the purpose and principles set out in section 38.<ref name="justiceYCJA39">Department of Justice Canada, 2008: "YCJA explained – section 39" Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 23, 2009, [http://canada.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103900.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605131310/http://canada.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103900.html |date=June 5, 2011 }}</ref>
39.(3) "In determining whether there is a reasonable alternative to custody, a youth justice court shall consider submissions relating to:
(a) the alternatives to custody that are available;
(b) the likelihood that the young person will comply with a non-custodial sentence, taking into account their compliance with previous non-custodial sentences; and
(c) the alternatives to custody that have been used in respect of young persons for similar offences committed in similar circumstances.<ref name="justiceYCJA39"/>
The above entails that even though a 'serious offence' was committed by a youth, it does not automatically equate to time in custody. The presiding official in a youth justice court '''must''' review all options other than custody by utilizing the factors outlined in 39 (3).<ref>Bala, Nicholas: "Youth Criminal Justice Law", page 450. Toronto: Irwin Law, 2002.</ref> Specifically section 39 (2) prohibits the court from imposing custody unless all alternatives have been considered.<ref>Department of Justice Canada, 2008. "Restrictions on Custody – Alternatives to Custody" Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 23, 2009, [http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301f.html JusticeCanada.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706183815/http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301f.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> The reason for said sections within the ''Act'' is to reduce the use of custody as a sentencing option, and consequently the number of youth in custody, and to ensure that the most intrusive response to youth offending is only used in serious cases.<ref>Bala, Nicholas: "Youth Criminal Justice Law", page 447. Toronto: Irwin Law, 2002.</ref> The inclusion of these sections displays a stark difference between the ''Young Offenders Act'' and the ''Youth Criminal Justice Act'' as the former did not have such clear preconditions that had to be satisfied prior to the imposition of a custodial sentence and thus large numbers of youth were incarcerated under the ''Young Offenders Act''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bala|first1= N.|last2= Carrington|first2= P. J.|last3=Roberts|first3= J. V.|year= 2009|title=Evaluating the Youth Criminal Justice Act after five years: a qualified success (Canada)|work= Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice, 51, 2. p.131(37)|accessdate= July 23, 2009|via= General OneFile via Gale|url= http://find.galegroup.com/itx/start.do?prodId=ITOF}} Group</ref>
===Reports for sentencing hearings=== '''Reports for sentencing hearings''' are used in more serious cases in order to assist in determining an appropriate sentence. The most frequently used report for sentencing hearings is the pre-sentence report which is outlined in section 40. The judge ultimately decides whether a report is necessary, though the crown may request the report and the defence counsel may argue against the issuing of a pre-sentence report. All custodial sentences require a pre-sentencing report. A pre-sentencing report is conducted by a government employee who interviews the youth and any significant influences including family members, peers and other important persons who may contribute to their report. This report is a historical outline which may include information regarding the youth's family background, school history, attitude toward their offence, willingness to engage in available community services, interview with the victim and potentially a suggestive sentence. The pre-sentence report is given to the judge, prosecutor and defence lawyers as well as the youth and any involved parent or guardian before the sentencing hearing.<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/>
====Restitution of property==== The ''Act'' requires that the personal circumstances of the young person be considered before ordering a sentence.<ref>The Law Students' Legal Advice Program Manual. 2008. "Chapter Two Youth Justice: Sentences." British Columbia, Canada: Law Students' Legal Advice Program, Retrieved July 16, 2009, [http://www.lslap.bc.ca/pdfs/06/2_YouthJustice.pdf LSLAP.bc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706165224/http://www.lslap.bc.ca/pdfs/06/2_YouthJustice.pdf |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> Custodial sentences are reserved for very serious offences (e.g., murder, manslaughter).<ref>Department of Justice. 2008. "Custodial Sentencing Options." Canada: Department of Justice, Retrieved July 16, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> The ''Act'' favours noncustodial sentencing options whenever possible in order to reduce the youth incarceration rates.
Restitution of property is a noncustodial sentencing option.<ref>Department of Justice. 2008. "Non-custodial Sentencing Options." Canada: Department of Justice, Retrieved July 16, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#noncustodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> According to this sentence, the young person is ordered to make restitution—that is, pay back the equivalent amount of the property obtained by the young person to the lawful owner of the property.<ref>Youth Criminal Justice Act. 2009. "Part 4 Sentencing: Youth Sentences." Canada: Department of Justice, Retrieved July 17, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41/20090714/en#anchorbo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> The youth justice court can fix the time and term of payment.<ref name="justiceYCJA42">Department of Justice. 2008. "Sentencing Options Table, YCJA, Section 42." Canada: Department of Justice, Retrieved July 17, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
Other considerations during this sentence include:<ref name="justiceYCJA42"/> * Allowing more time for completion of the sentence. * Notifying the person to whom the restitution will be made about the sentencing order. * The obtained property must be in possession of the young person at the time, and must lawfully belong to the owner of the property.
===Sentencing principles===
====Comparison with adult sentences==== Under sentencing principle (3) (a) of the ''Act'', the sentencing of a youth's punishment should not by any means be harsher or surpass that of the punishment for an adult who has been found [[Guilty (law)|guilty]] of committing the same crime as the youth<ref>"YCJA Explained – Legislation." Department of Justice Canada. December 13, 2008, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/6000001a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502144046/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/6000001a.html |date=May 2, 2009 }}</ref> The reason for this sentencing principle was to eliminate discrepancies that were prevalent in the ''[[Young Offenders Act]]''. It was formed on the basis that youth under the Young Offenders Act were receiving longer sentences than adults for the same offences. In R. v. C.D.; [2005] a youth plead guilty to arson, breach of a recognisance, and the possession of a weapon.<ref name="Umontreal.ca">"Supreme Court of Canada – Decisions – R. v. C.D." Judgements of the Supreme Court of Canada. December 16, 2005, [http://csc.lexum.umontreal.ca/en/2005/2005scc78/2005scc78.html Umontreal.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926141730/http://csc.lexum.umontreal.ca/en/2005/2005scc78/2005scc78.html |date=September 26, 2008 }}</ref> He received a light sentence of six months of deferred custody due to the Youth Criminal Justice Act.<ref name="Umontreal.ca"/> Appeals against this case, state that the youth has committed an [[indictable offence]] for which an adult would be imprisoned for a period of two or more years.<ref name="Umontreal.ca"/>
====Similarity==== Under the sentencing principle 38 (2)(b)of the ''Young Criminal Justice Act'', the court requires that the sentence imposed must be similar in the region when young offenders are found guilty of the same crime under similar circumstances.<ref>Canadian Legal Information Institute. 2005. "Youth Criminal Justice Act, S.C. 2002, c. 1" Federation of Law Societies of Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/sc-2002-c-1/latest/sc-2002-c-1.html CANLII.org]</ref> This means that there should be a general level of consistency in sentences for young offenders who are guilty of the same crime. This principle addresses the unfair disparity of youth sentences, by stating that sentence should be similar, not necessarily the same<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008." Sentencing Principles (Subsection 38(2))" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033008/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> Allowing such individualization makes the sentence meaningful for the youth involved and points at any rehabilitative needs required by the young offender.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008." Sentencing Principles (Subsection 38(2))" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033008/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> These sentencing principles are meant to be imposed in accordance to additional principles listed out in section 38 (3) which state that in determining the youth sentence, the court shall take in account: the degree of participation of subjected youth in offence, the degree of harm inflicted and intentions of offender, any reparations provided to victim or community by youth offender, any time spent in detention by youth due to offense, any other case of guilt found against the offender, and whether there is any additional aggravating or mitigating information against the offender that might influence the sentence read otherwise.<ref>Youth Crime Defense Office. 2008. "Sentencing under the Youth Criminal Justice Act (YCJA)" Department of Justice Canada Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.ycdo.ca/legal/sentencing.htm YCDO.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504033422/http://www.ycdo.ca/legal/sentencing.htm |date=May 4, 2009 }}</ref>
====Proportionality==== The sentencing principle 38 (2)(c)under the ''Act'' states 'the sentence must be proportionate to the seriousness of the offence and the degree of responsibility of the young person for that offence'<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycjalsjpa/60103800.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033044/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycjalsjpa/60103800.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> Sentencing principles clearly explain the basis that establish fair and justifiable sentences. Under the Youth Criminal Justice Act punishments are not only limited to jail imprisonment in addition extrajudicial measures are taken such as community services and probation.<ref>Pulis, Jessica E., Scott, Jane B.," Probation sentences and proportionality under the Young Offenders Act and the Youth Criminal Justice Act" Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3204/is_4_47/ai_n29224759/ FindArticles.com]</ref> The punishment is given to the offender according to the gravity of his/her offence. For young offenders, cases are viewed individually and sentencing is determined distinctively for different cases. Thus the more serious the offence is the more severe the punishment will be. Proportionality here means the size or the degree of the offence, thus the punishment should be proportional to the crime committed.<ref>Brodie, Scott. 2002. Changes in Custody Following the Enactment Of the Youth Criminal Justice Act. Retrieved July 23, 2009, [http://ir.lib.sfu.ca/dspace/retrieve/2352/etd1943.pdf SFU.ca]</ref> So a young offender who commits murder will be will severely punished compared to someone who steals. How serious was the offence, the offender's level of participation and their intention, the harm done to the victim and the previous findings of the guilt are taken in account by the court to determine the sentencing of the offence.
====Substitute to custody==== Under the sentencing principle 38 2(d), the court is required to consider a substitute for the custody of young persons, while paying special attention to aboriginal offenders.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033008/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60103800.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> In addition, the section also states that special concern should be given to youth by taking into account the gender, racial, and cultural differences. By responding to the needs of young aboriginal offenders, the focus of this section directs the court to use less harsh custodial sentences except when the offender poses a great threat to the public.<ref name="ir.lib.sfu.ca">Brodie, Scott. 2002. Changes in Custody Following the Enactment Of the Youth Criminal Justice Act. Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://ir.lib.sfu.ca/dspace/retrieve/2352/etd1943.pdf SFU.ca]</ref> "Special attention to the circumstances of Aboriginal offenders is mandated by the-minute amendments to the YCJA initiated by the Senate".<ref>Roach, Kent. 2003. "The Role of Crime Victims Under the Youth Criminal Justice Act". Alberta Law Review, Vol. 40(40) pp. 965–989</ref> An example of this is seen in R. V. D.R.D. (2006), in which a fourteen-year-old boy was pleaded guilty of trafficking and was appealing his sentence for drug charges. He was convicted to one year probation because the judge maintained that he is an extreme aboriginal youth which is a risk to the society.<ref name="ir.lib.sfu.ca"/>
===Sentencing options=== '''Sentencing Option 42 (2) (a)''' Sentencing option 42(2) under the ''Act'' is to reprimand the young person. Reprimand is a severe reproof or rebuke in this case by a person of authority.
'''Sentencing Option 42 (2)(b)''' When a young person is found guilty, through a youth justice court, the judge may refer to section 42(2)(b) under the ''Act''.<ref name="sentencing60104200">Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> Under section 42(2)(b) a young person, when guilt is found, may be discharged absolutely.<ref name="efc.ca">Electronic Frontier Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.efc.ca/pages/law/cc/cc.736.html EFC.ca]</ref> This discharge is dependent on the best interest of the young offender without being in contrast with the best interests of the public.<ref name="efc.ca"/> An absolute discharge, under section 42(2)(b), in accordance with 82(2), constitutes a termination of the sentence of a young person in respect of an offence in which a young person is found guilty.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Effect of absolute discharge or termination of youth sentence", Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60108200.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033117/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60108200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> As opposed to conditional discharges, absolute discharges do not carry sanctions of probation or any other condition that the court may find appropriate (fair sanctions with meaningful consequences)<ref>Understanding the Youth Criminal Justice Act. 2005. "Sentencing" Corrections & Public Safety, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.cpsp.gov.sk.ca/Default.aspx?DN=b72b2803-4d3e-4059-9d09-5a1536e6a6ac Gov.sk.ca]</ref>
'''Sentencing Option 42 (2)(c)''' Sentencing option 42 (2) c under the ''Act'' states that a convicted young offender can be discharged on any conditions the court decides to be appropriate.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> This may require the young offender to report to and be supervised by the provincial director.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> Conditions for a discharge might also include undergoing counselling, doing community service work or donation to a charity. Once the duration of the discharge has passed and the conditions of the probation have been successfully followed, the discharge becomes absolute, i.e., the youth will not be viewed as the offender although the record can be used for three years after finding of guilt in the event that there is a subsequent conviction.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bala|first= Nicholas|year= 2002|title=Youth Criminal Justice Law - Essential of Canadian Law|accessdate= July 26, 2009|page= 432}}</ref> However, if the young person fails to abide by the conditions of probation, the offender can be convicted of the original offence and be sentenced.<ref>Sentencing In Canada. 1999. "Absolute and Conditional Discharge" Sentencing Options In Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/PUB/C33.htm#Abso JohnHoward.ab.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231203343/http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/C33.htm |date=December 31, 2011 }}</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(c)''' If a young person is found guilty, "By order direct that the young person be discharged on any conditions that the court considers appropriate and may require the young person to report to and be supervised by the provincial director".<ref name="sentencing60104200"/> As an order under conditional release, the young offender is required to follow certain rules set out by a probation order for a specific length of time; when the time duration has passed, the release becomes absolute.<ref>Electronic Frontier Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.efc.ca/pages/law/cc/cc.736.html EFC.ca]</ref> The considerations for conditional discharge must be in the best interest of the offender and not contrary to public interest. The purpose of this section is to reduce the rate of incarceration of young people and promote rehabilitation and reintegration into society.<ref name="YCJA"/> If any condition is violated by the young offender, they will be required to appear in front of the court again at which point they may be incarcerated.<ref name=autogenerated4>Barnhorst, R., (2006). "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: New Directions and Implementation Issues". Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice. 46(3). pp. 231–250.</ref> Examples of conditions placed on the young offender are as follows: *Abstain from alcohol or drug use<ref name="YCJA"/> *Abstain from owning, possessing or carrying a weapon<ref name="YCJA"/> *Perform community service<ref name="YCJA"/> *Participate in a treatment program<ref name="YCJA"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(d)''' If a young person is found guilty of an offence in a youth justice court, the judge may impose a sentence under section 42 of the ''Act''.<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> The purpose of sentencing under the ''Act'' "is to hold a young person accountable for an offence by imposing fair sanctions with meaningful consequences."<ref>Understanding the Youth Criminal Justice Act. 2005. "Sentencing" Corrections & Public Safety, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.cpsp.gov.sk.ca/Default.aspx?DN=b72b2803-4d3e-4059-9d09-5a1536e6a6ac Gov.sk.ca]</ref> Under section 42(2)(d) it states that a young offender may not have a fine against them exceeding $1000 to be paid at the time and on the terms that the court may fix.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> This entails that the courts must have regard to the means of how the young offender will pay, as well as the ability for the young offender to be granted more time to complete the sentence. The offender then has the following options, he or she may be ordered to pay a victim fine surcharge (up to 15%) which contributes to assisting the victims of the crime. Or, the province may establish a program under which the young offender can discharge a fine under para, the percentage imposed under s53(1) or Victim fine surcharge under s 53(2) which is only attainable by earning credits for work in the program of the province the young offender resides.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42 (2)(e)''' Section 42(2)(e) under the ''Act'' states that the young person must pay to the other person at the time/terms that the court fixes the amount of compensation due to loss of income/support, damage of property etc.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved August 14, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(h)''' Section 42 (2) (h) under the ''Act'' is a non- custodial sentencing option that states that the Youth Justice Court (YJC) may order a young offender to compensate the victim in kind or by personal service for a damage, loss, or injury suffered.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Non-Custodial Sentencing Options". Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html Department Justice of Canada] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> Under 42 (2) (h), an order may be made under section 42 (2) (g) where the young offender is to monetarily compensate the purchaser of a stolen property since the stolen property had to be returned to the owner, or section 42 (2) (e) where the young offender is to monetarily compensate the victim for personal injury or property that was damaged.<ref>Bala, Nicolas. 2003. "Youth Criminal Justice Law". Toronto: Irwin Law.</ref> The YJC may arrange the times and terms of compensation that is ordered. However, the compensation must not conflict with the young offender's regular schedule of education and work.<ref name="sentencing3040501">Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Sentencing Options Table, YCJA, Section 42". Retrieved July 24, 2009, from Department Justice of Canada [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> The order to provide personal service to the victim can be assigned for any number of hours but is limited up to 240 hours.<ref name="sentencing3040501"/> The hours of service ordered can be completed within one year from the date which the sentencing option was ordered; however the YJC may allow an extension of time to fully complete the sentence, on application of the young offender.<ref name="sentencing3040501"/> Although the YJC may order the young offender to compensate the victim by providing personal service, the consent of the compensated is required.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008. "Sentencing Options Table, YCJA, Section 42". Retrieved July 24, 2009, from Department Justice of Canada, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(i)''' In the ''Act'', under Sentencing options 42 (2) (i), the court has the option to order a young person to complete community service for a punishment. The amount of community service must not go beyond 240 hours of service which can be completed within 12 months.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009n [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> The community service must be approved by the provincial director of the youth justice court or a person designated by the youth justice court.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Justice Renewal" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html#ss2i Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> The purpose of sentencing under section 42 is to protect society by holding the young person accountable for their actions by giving the right amount of punishment which can promote their rehabilitation and reintegration into society.<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> This type of sentencing is a non custodial sentencing option which is the goal of the Youth Criminal Justice act to not rely on the over use of incarceration for non violent youths. It also gives out different options which can be costumed to different individual cases that can give out the best solution possible. These are the innovations that were created due to the Youth Criminal Justice Act, it helps youth to get the best rehabilitation to continue on their lives in society.<ref name="justiceyouthsentencing3040301"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(k)''' Section 42(2)(k) under the ''Act'' allows a young person to be placed on '''Probation''' (as specified by conditions and other matters related to probation orders under sections 55 and 56) for a specified period of time not exceeding two years.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = [[Department of Justice (Canada)|Department of Justice]] | year = 2008 | title = Youth Sentencing Options | accessdate = July 25, 2009 | url = http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110614032734/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60104200.html | archivedate = June 14, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Orders may range from being supervised by the provincial director; remain within the territorial jurisdiction of one or more courts; attending school; or having to reside at a place specified by the provincial director. The Youth Justice Court prescribes these conditions as an order so the young person will learn to be of good behaviour and appear before the youth justice court when required to do so.
Probation is the sentence most frequently imposed by youth justice courts in Canada, as the conditions laid out are directly related to the young offenders criminal behaviour. This helps the offender to see the harm caused by their actions to the society and victims, and why they should not commit such crimes again.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bala|first= Nicholas|year= 2002|title=Youth Criminal Justice Law - Essential of Canadian Law|accessdate= July 25, 2009 |url= http://site.ebrary.com|pages= 432–433}}</ref> If a young offender fails to comply with the probation order, they can possibly be charged with breach of probation. But th ''Act'' does not require the charges be laid; rather, it states that an alternative approach is recommended. Such as a review of probation orders thus providing an opportunity to make changes to conditions that can be more effective in promoting the rehabilitation and reintegration of the young person.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42 (2) (l)''' To ensure that a young offenders illegal actions are followed by consequences that are "(1)just; (2)have meaningful consequences for the youth; (3) and promote the rehabilitation and reintegration of the youth into society"<ref>Barnhorst, Richard. 2004. "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: New Directions and Implementation Issues". Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice 46(3):231–250.</ref> the ''Act'' has instilled several sentencing options.
According to Section 42(2), the twelfth sentencing option for youth is the placement in an '''(l) intensive support and supervision program'''.<ref name="Youth Criminal Justice Act 2002"/> This non-custodial sentencing option was introduce to the act along with options such as reprimand as well as non-residential programs or attendance orders.<ref>Minaker, Joanne C. & Hogeveen, Bryan. 2009. Youth, Crime, and Society. Toronto: Pearson Education Canada.</ref>
This sentencing option is meant to be an alternative for custody, and was implemented to decrease high rates of custody caused by the ''Young Offenders Act''.<ref name="Justice Canada 2002">Department of Justice Canada. (2002). "Youth Criminal Justice Act Explained: Youth Sentencing". Retrieved, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/pdf/3040301.pdf Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181715/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/pdf/3040301.pdf |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> The young offender receives support and supervision from their community in hopes that they will alter their behaviour. The intent of this sentencing option is to provide more support than probation<ref name="Justice Canada 2002"/> and is often used to promote the use of community-based and rehabilitation sentences.<ref name="Bala, Nicholas 2003">Bala, Nicholas. 2003. Youth Criminal Justice Law. Toronto: Irwin Law Inc.</ref>
This option encourages the rehabilitation of the youth and should target the specific needs or problems that seem to have contributed to their illegal behaviour.<ref name="Justice Canada 2002"/>
This sentencing option will only take place if the government has established programs and the courts have received approval of the provincial director.<ref name="Bala, Nicholas 2003"/> If not available, a probation order will be used along with various conditions to ensure the support and supervision of the youth in question.<ref name="Justice Canada 2002"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42 (2) (m)'''
This new sentencing option requires, at specific times, a young offender to attend court sanctioned programs. Over a six-month period a maximum of 240 hours that can be assigned.<ref name="dss-snd.gc.ca">Department of Justice Canada. (2002). "Data Standards Secretariat", [http://www.dss-snd.gc.ca/publication/en/code/code0292.html GC.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081103002646/http://www.dss-snd.gc.ca/publication/en/code/code0292.html |date=November 3, 2008 }}</ref>
This sentencing option is a nonresidential program that may be used as an alternative to custody and may be focused at specific high-risk times of day, such as when the youth may be unattended and unsupervised.<ref name="YCJAexplained">Department of Justice Canada. (2002). "Youth Criminal Justice Act Explained: Youth Sentencing", [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/pdf/3040301.pdf Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181715/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/pdf/3040301.pdf |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
A Pilot attendance centre program in Ontario has reported considerable success and was well received by Ontario youth court judges.<ref name="Justice Canada 2009">Department of Justice Canada. (2009). "Youth Sentencing options", [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#regular Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref>
This measure may only occur if and attendance order program is available in the province. Provinces may decide not to implement this provision of the ''Act'' and are not required to make this option available.<ref name="Justice Canada 2009"/>
Due to potential high costs associated with this program, provinces may be eligible for additional federal funding.<ref name="YCJAexplained"/>
In the absence of such programs, a youth court judge may achieve similar ends by attaching specific conditions to a probation order handed down to a young person. The judge may also (as a condition of probation) require the young person to attend community programs.<ref name="Justice Canada 2002"/><ref name="dss-snd.gc.ca"/>
The overall goal of attendance programs is to supervise young persons at times when they may be more prone to commit crimes, such as when left unattended by parents.<ref name="Justice Canada 2009"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(n)''' The ''Act'' states that all [[custodial sentence]]s must have a mandatory period of supervision in the community.<ref>Minaker, Joanne C. & Hogeveen, Bryan. (2009). Youth, Crime and Society – Issues of Power and Justice . Toronto: Pearson Education Canada.</ref> The rationale behind the community supervision order is to provide support and supervision for the young offender's transition from custody back into their community.<ref name="Justice Canada 2008">Department of Justice Canada . (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing Options. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#regular Department of Justice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref>
When a judge sentences a young offender to a custody and supervision order under Section 42(2) (n) of the ''Act'', it means that the young offender must serve time in custody, followed by a period of supervision in the community. The supervision order may be up to half as long as the custodial period.<ref>Department of Justice Canada . (December 12, 2008). Sentencing Options Table, YCJA,Section 42. Retrieved July 22, 2009, from Department of Justice Canada, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> This sentencing option is for convicted youth criminals who are convicted for crimes other than murder, [[attempted murder]], [[manslaughter]], [[aggravated sexual assault]] or who are in custody as a result of an IRCS (Intensive Rehabilitative Custody and Supervision) order.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 12, 2008). Sentencing Options Table, YCJA,Section 42. Retrieved July 22, 2009, from Department of Justice Canada, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
The length of the custodial sentence and supervision order combined must not exceed two or three years, depending on the type of offence.<ref>Bala, N. (2002). Youth Criminal Justice Law. Irwin Law.</ref> Offences other than for which an adult would receive life imprisonment are subject to a two-year maximum for the young offender. Offences for which an adult would receive life imprisonment, except murder, are subject to a three-year maximum for the young offender.<ref name="Justice Canada 2008"/>
If a condition laid out by the judge or other officials is broken, or not met appropriately while under supervision in the community, reviews are held which determine whether the young offender's conditions should be changed or if he or she should be sent back into custody.<ref name="Justice Canada 2008"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(o)''' Section 42(2)(o) of the ''Act'' establishes the length of time to be served in custody or in community supervision for cases of attempted murder, [[manslaughter]], [[aggravated sexual assault]].<ref>Department of justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing options. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from Department of Justice, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> The total serving time for these periods cannot exceed 3 years since life imprisonment is imposed on adults responsible for these offences.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008) Youth Sentencing options. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from Department of Justice, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> Under the ''Act'', murder is the only offence that must result in a custody and supervision order. The maximum serving time is 10 years for [[first-degree murder]] and 7 years for [[second-degree murder]].<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing Options. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from Department of Justice, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref>
Section 42(2) (o) also asserts the ability of the court to decide the duration of conditional supervision. Thus the supervision period does not have to be half the period of custody.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing options. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from Department of Justice, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#custodial Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> This condition provides more liberty for the courts to respond with an appropriate sentence to serious offences. If a young person violates a condition during the supervision period, the provincial director may place the offender back into custody.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing options. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from Youth Criminal Justice Act, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_4/20090723/en#anchorbo-ga:l_4 Justice.gc.ca]</ref>
For other statutory considerations, the supervision part of the order includes mandatory and discretionary conditions (s. 105).<ref name="ReferenceA">Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Sentencing Option Tables. Retrieved July 27, 2009, from the [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Department of Justice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> Also, the amount of time served in custody by a young person can be extended via AG or provincial director's request to the YJC. However, the added duration of custody may not surpass the remainder of the youth sentence (s. 104).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(p)''' Under section 42(2)(p) of the ''Act'', a judge may impose a deferred custody and supervision order as a sentencing option.<ref>Department of Justice Canada. (December 13, 2008). Youth Sentencing Options.
