Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html#regular Department of Justice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> A deferred custody and supervision order means that the young offender will not go into custody but will serve their sentence under supervision in the community with a set of strict conditions.<ref>Statistics Canada Definitions, (May 13, 2009), retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/2009002/definitions-eng.htm#d1 StatCan.gc.ca]</ref> If these conditions are not followed, then the conditions may be changed and the young person may be ordered to serve the balance of the sentence in custody.<ref>Specific Youth Sentences, Justice for Children and Youth, Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.jfcy.org/ycj-youth.html JFCY.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531075318/http://www.jfcy.org/ycj-youth.html |date=May 31, 2009 }}</ref> The order will be made if the offense committed is not a serious, violent one such as murder or aggravated assault, and if the young person has not committed an [[indictable offence]] that an adult would be imprisoned for, for more than two years. The order will be for six months or less and must be considered a just sanction that has meaningful consequences and will promote the young offender's rehabilitation and reintegration into society and contribute to the long-term protection of the public. The order will include both strict mandatory and optional conditions that the judge deems appropriate and which fall under subsection 105(2) and 105(3). These conditions will include reporting to the provincial director, attending school and/or working, not possessing weapons, abiding by curfews, reporting information changes and others.<ref>Deferred Custody and Supervision Order Conditions , (2009,May 25) Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.albertacourts.ab.ca/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=BMo1pn1Pvlg%3D&tabid=321&mid=829 AlbertaCourts.ab.ca]</ref>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(q)''' The ''Act'' section 42 (2) (q) outlines the following pertaining to custody and supervision for [[Murder#First and second degree|1st and 2nd degree murder]]<ref name="ReferenceB">Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Sentencing Options Table, YCJA,Section 42." Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 21, 2009 from the [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Department of Justice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> Offenders found guilty of 1st degree murder will get a maximum sentence of 10 years, including a maximum custody period of 6 years and a period of conditional supervision in the community.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Offenders found guilty of 2nd Degree Murder will get a 7-year maximum sentence including a maximum custody period of 4 years and a period of conditional supervision in the community.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Other statutory considerations are that the Attorney General or a provincial director may apply to extend the length of time the young person will spend in custody. The extension may not exceed the remainder of the youth sentence.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> At least one month prior to the expiration of the custodial portion of the sentence, the YJC sets conditions of the young person's conditional supervision<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The aforementioned sentences are not guaranteed as the Crown could recommend a harsher adult sentence if the offence meets certain requirements [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/pdf/3050301.pdf(see Adult Sentence)]<ref name="site.ebrary.com"/> When the ''Act'' was introduced the aspect that was publicized was ''"to respond more firmly and effectively to the small number of the most serious, violent young offenders"'' because the public was losing confidence in the youth justice system<ref name="find.galegroup.com">Bal, Carrington and Roberts. 2009. "Evaluating the Youth Criminal Justice Act and Five Years: A Qualified Success." Canadian Journal of Criminology and Criminal Justice, Retrieved July 21, 2009, [http://find.galegroup.com/itx/retrieve.do?contentSet=IACDocuments&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&qrySerId=Locale%28en%2CUS%2C%29%3AHQE%3D%28__HR__%2CNone%2C43%29sn+1707-7753+and+iu+2+and+sp+131+and+vo+51+24&sgHitCountType=None&inPS=true&sort=DateDescend&searchType=CCLSearchForm&tabID=T002&prodId=ITOF&searchId=R1&currentPosition=1&userGroupName=utoronto_main&docId=A200339949&docType=IAC gale]</ref> This was the reason for the harsh penalties for first- and second- degree murder, however, overall, the ''Act'' has decreased the number of youths within jails for non-violent offences substantially.<ref name="find.galegroup.com"/>
'''Sentencing Options 42(2)(r).''' This section provides that a judge may issue an intensive rehabilitative custody and supervision order. This sentence is intended to provide treatment for serious violent offenders. The court may only issue this order if any of the following criteria are met: * the young person has been found guilty of murder, attempted murder, manslaughter, aggravated sexual assault, or a third serious violent offence<ref name="ReferenceC">Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Youth Sentencing Options" Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719031551/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301h.html |date=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> * the young person is found to be suffering from a mental or psychological disorder<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * an individualized treatment plan for the young person has been developed<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * the provincial director has determined that an intensive rehabilitative custody and supervision program is an available and suitable option<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
This section applies to young people ages twelve to seventeen as long as one or more of these conditions are met. The Youth Justice Court must specify the time period the order is applicable for. The maximum period for an intensive rehabilitative custody and supervision order is 2 years, unless the adult penalty for the offence is imprisonment for life, in those cases the maximum period is 3 years. The only other exceptions occur in the case of:<ref>YCJA Youth Sentencing. 2002, "45,S.42(2)(r) Intensive Rehabilitative Custody and Supervision Order" side 45, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.albertacourts.ab.ca/pc/youth/ycja/YouthSentencing.ppt#361,45,S.42(2) AlbertaCourts.ab.ca]</ref>
* 1st Degree Murder: maximum period is 10 years including a maximum custody period of 6 years and a period of supervision in the community<ref name="ReferenceD">Department of Justice Canada. 2008."Sentencing Options Table, YCJA, Section 42." Department of Justice Canada, Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181707/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040501a.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> * 2nd Degree Murder: The maximum period is 7 years including a maximum custody period of 4 years and a period of supervision in the community<ref name="ReferenceD"/>
'''Section 55 (2) (g)''' When the youth is sentenced to probation he or she is subject to certain conditions that may be imposed by the judge<ref>Department of Justice Canada. 2008. Youth Justice Renewal Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5//20090725/en?command=search&caller=SI&fragment=Youth%20Criminal%20Justice%20Act%20Section%2055%20&search_type=all&day=25&month=7&year=2009&search_domain=cs&showall=L&statuteyear=all&lengthannual=50&length=50 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> Under Section 55 (2) (g) the young offender may be told to "reside at a place that the provincial director may specify"<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. Youth Justice Renewal Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60105500.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033124/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60105500.html |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> This condition follows 2 other requirements that the young offender also needs to obey by a) keep the peace and be of good behaviour; and b) appear by the youth justice court when required by the court to do so<ref>John Howard Society. 2007. "Youth Criminal Justice Act Handbook" Criminal Justice Education. Retrieved July 25, 2009 from [http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf JohnHoward.ab.ca] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802120035/http://www.johnhoward.ab.ca/pub/youthcrim/youth.pdf |date=August 2, 2010 }}</ref> this stated in Section 55 (1). The probation conditions follow those stipulated under section 42(2)(k) or (l). This means the director has the power to indicate where they want you to live, moving you from one area to the next depending on the circumstances surrounding the young offender's situation.
'''Section 59: Review of Non-Custodial Youth Sentences''' Under the ''Young Offender's Act'', approximately 20% of custody sentences were charged based on "failure to comply" issues surrounding probation orders<ref name="noncustodial">Department of Justice Canada.2008. "Reviews of Non Custodial Sentencing" Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301j.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181727/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/04you-ado/3040301j.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> The ''Youth Criminal Justice Act'' revised these procedures recognizing that most issues concerning the violation of probation conditions were not criminal acts themselves and that in doing so, were compromising the integrity of the justice system itself. Therefore, the ''Act'' considers a review, rather than a charge, as a means of reducing the reliance on incarceration while being as fair as possible to the offender in assessing the seriousness of an offence<ref name="noncustodial"/>
The ''Act'' reveals that a review, "can be issued at any time after six months of the initial youth sentence or, with leave of a youth justice court judge"<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "Review of Youth Sentences Not Involving Custody, YCJA, Section 59". Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41/20090723/en#anchorbo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> (56). Also, reviews, in most cases, are exempt from those offenders who are charge with an offence outlined in section 42 of the ''Act''. The full grounds for review are revealed under section 59.2 and are as follows:
*(a) on the ground that the circumstances that led to the youth sentence have changed materially; *(b) on the ground that the young person in respect of whom the review is to be made is unable to comply with or is experiencing serious difficulty in complying with the terms of the youth sentence; *(c) on the ground that the young person in respect of whom the review is to be made has contravened a condition of an order made under paragraph 42(2)(k) or (l) without reasonable excuse; *(d) on the ground that the terms of the youth sentence are adversely affecting the opportunities available to the young person to obtain services, education or employment; or *(e) on any other ground that the youth justice court considers appropriate<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "Review of Youth Sentences Not Involving Custody, YCJA, Section 59". Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41/20090723/en#anchorbo-ga:l_4-gb:s_41 Justice.gc.ca]</ref>
===Adult sentence=== If a young person is found guilty of an indictable offence, an offence where an adult would be liable to receive more than two years, an order for an adult sentence shall be imposed on a young offender in the following cases: * if the young person indicates that he or she doesn't want to make an application for a youth sentence or fails to make an indication,<ref name=ref1>Department of Justice Canada. 2002. " Youth Criminal Justice Act (2002, c.1)." Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5//20090726/en?command=search&caller=SI&fragment=youth%20criminal%20justice%20act&search_type=all&day=26&month=7&year=2009&search_domain=cs&showall=L&statuteyear=all&lengthannual=50&length=50 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> or if the purpose and principles set out in subparagraph 3(1)(b)(ii) and section 38 would not have sufficient length to hold the young person accountable for their offending behaviour in the case of a presumptive offence<ref name="ref1" /> or * In any other case, if the young person gives notice to the [[Youth Justice Court|youth justice court]] that he or she doesn't oppose the application for an adult sentence,<ref name="ref1" /> or if the purpose and principles set out in subparagraph 3(1)(b)(ii) and section 38 would not have sufficient length to hold the young person accountable for their offending behaviour in relation to an offence committed after the young offender has just acquired fourteen years of age.<ref name="ref1" />
There are three categories of offences that may attract an adult sentence: # Presumptive "a" offences: Specified offences (murder, attempted murder, manslaughter, aggravated sexual assault)<ref name=ref2>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "The YCJA Explained-Modules-Adult Sentences-Explanatory Text." Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/05adult/3050301a.htm Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614033139/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/05adult/3050301a.htm |date=June 14, 2011 }}</ref> # Presumptive "b" offences: repeating of serious violent offence<ref name="ref2" /> # Non-presumptive offences<ref name="ref2" /> There are a few important changes to ''Act'' compared to the ''Young Offenders Act'', for example, the transfer process from a youth court to an adult court is eliminated. Instead, the youth court first determines whether or not the young person is guilty of the offence, and then, under certain circumstances, the youth court may impose an adult sentence,<ref name="canada.justice.gc.ca"/>
'''When the Crown does not seek an adult sentence for presumptive offence'''<br /> Section 65 of the ''Act'' states that if the Attorney General gives notice to the court at any stage of the proceedings that the young offender, who is alleged to have committed a "presumptive offence" (as mentioned above) that an adult sentence would not be sought, the court shall order that the young individual is not liable to an adult sentence; the youth would immediately be tried in youth court and a youth sentence would be imposed.<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: Section 65." Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60106500.html Justice.gc.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181730/http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60106500.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> <br>Under this ''Act'', the publication ban would be in effect, in accordance with Section 110 which states that no one shall publish the name or any information related to the young person if it would identify the individual.<ref>Quebec (Minister of Justice) v. Canada (Minister of Justice), 2003 CanLII 52182 (QC C.A.).2003."CanLII: Quebec: Court of Appeal". Retrieved July 24, 2009, [http://www.canlii.org/eliisa/highlight.do?text=section+65+YCJA&language=en&searchTitle=Search+all+CanLII+Databases&path=/en/qc/qcca/doc/2003/2003canlii52182/2003canlii52182.html CANLII.org]</ref><br /> <br>This act was posted in Bill C-3 under Clause 64.<ref>Government of Canada.2002. "Bill C-3: The Youth Criminal Justice Act" Government of Canada. Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://dsp-psd.tpsgc.gc.ca/Collection-R/LoPBdP/LS/362/c3-e.htm GC.ca]</ref><br /> <br>This act applies in accordance to the seriousness and circumstances of the offence, and the age, maturity, character, background and previous record of the young person and any other factors considered relevant (Section 72).<ref>Department of Justice Canada.2008. "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: Section 72." Canada: Department of Justice Canada. Retrieved July 25, 2009, [http://justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/6legisln/01ycja-lsjpa/60107200.html#ss1 Justice.gc.ca]</ref> In addition, the age for presumptive offences was lowered to fourteen, causing a lot of doubts have been brought up to whether a fourteen-year-old should be treated in the same fashion as adults, especially when there are other pieces of criminal legislation (proposed and already in existence), recognizing their immature status.<ref>Canadian Youth Criminal Justice Act. Retrieved July 26, 2009, [http://www.lawyers.ca/ycja/index.htm Lawyers.ca]</ref>
===Serious violent offences=== The ''Act'' defines a ''serious violent offence'' as an offence in the commission of which a young person causes or attempts to cause serious [[bodily harm]].<ref>Valiquet, Dominique (2007). "Legislative Summaries". Law and Government Division. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/LegislativeSummaries/Bills_ls.asp?lang=E&ls=c25&source=library_prb&Parl=39&Ses=2#footnote41 Parl.gc.ca]</ref> A ''serious violent offence'' can become a presumptive offence if the young person has previously committed two violent offences. ''Presumptive offence'' means that the young person, over the age of 14, can receive an adult sentence if they are found guilty.<ref>Department of Justice (2008). "YCJA Explained". Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 20, 2009, [http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/05adult/3050301b.html JusticeCanada.ca] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706183819/http://justicecanada.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/repos-depot/3modules/05adult/3050301b.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> If a young person is charged for a serious violent offence, they will be sentenced for "intensive rehabilitative custody and supervision order". It is an individualized treatment plan. <br /> The court can make this order in specific circumstances:<ref>Department of Justice (2008). "The Youth Criminal Justice Act: Summary and Background". Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 21, 2009, [https://web.archive.org/web/20080602012655/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/pi/yj-jj/ycja-lsjpa/back-hist.html Justice.gc.ca]</ref>
*If the young person has been found guilty of murder, [[attempted murder]], manslaughter, [[aggravated sexual assault]] or has committed at least two serious violent offences in the past *The young person is suffering from a mental or [[psychological disorder]] or an emotional disturbance *There are reasonable grounds to believe that the treatment plan might reduce the risk of the young person repeating the offence or committing other presumptive offences *An appropriate program is available and the young person is suitable for admission.
===Breach of probation=== Section 137 of the ''Act'' outlines the definitions and consequences of failing to comply with a sentence or disposition, in other words, a breach of probation. It states that anyone failing to comply with their probation order is guilty of a punishable offence on a summary conviction.<ref name="laws.justice.gc.ca"/> These orders can include failure to report to and be supervised by the provincial director when on probation, failure to perform community service plus many more stated in section 42(2) of the act.<ref name="laws.justice.gc.ca">Department of Justice, (2009) "Youth Criminal Justice Act". Canada: Department of Justice. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/Y-1.5/bo-ga:l_5/20090723/en Justice.gc.ca]</ref> If a breach of probation occurs, the offender may be incarcerated provided it is not their first probation violation, with a sentence not exceeding two years, except in the cases of first-degree murder or second-degree murder.<ref name="laws.justice.gc.ca"/>
'''Differences in breach of probation in the ''Youth Criminal Justice Act'' versus ''Youth Offenders Act'''''
The ''Young Offenders Act'' raised concern that too many young people were being incarcerated for offences not directly harming the community, but for failure to comply with the terms of probation.<ref name="papers.ssrn.com">Bala, N. (2007). "Responding to Young Offenders: Diversion, Detention, & Sentencing Under Canada's Y.C.J.A.". Faculty of Law; Kingston, ON. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1023893 SSRN.com]</ref> The ''Act'' recognizes that youths have a hard time complying with limits to behaviour and are deserving of a second chance.<ref name="papers.ssrn.com"/> Since the ''Act'' was enacted, the number of charges of probation violation has remained similar while the number of cases has declined.<ref>Robinson, P. (2003). "Youth Court Statistics" Canada: Centre for Justice Statistics. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://dsp-psd.tpsgc.gc.ca/Collection-R/Statcan/85-002-XIE/0020485-002-XIE.PDF GC.ca]</ref><ref>Thomas, J. (2004). "Youth Court Statistics" Canada: Centre for Justice Statistics. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://dsp-psd.tpsgc.gc.ca/Collection-R/Statcan/85-002-XIE/0040585-002-XIE.PDF GC.ca]</ref><ref>Thomas, J. (2007). "Youth Court Statistics" Canada: Centre for Justice Statistics. Retrieved July 22, 2009, [http://dsp-psd.pwgsc.gc.ca/collection_2008/statcan/85-002-X/85-002-XIE2008004.pdf GC.ca]</ref>
